entry.title: Some Are Better..
entry.content:
Some are better loved from a distance.

For a while, anyway.

And that’s OK.

Besides, love doesn’t really know the difference.

http://www.tut.com

entry.title: Had Quite a Few...
entry.content:
“I had quite a few pints and quite a few beers and quite a few glasses of red wine, and it all continued until about 30 minutes ago. Have to enjoy it when you can.”

“I definitely appreciate an awful lot more what I’ve achieved now than what I did then. Ten years ago I did take an awful lot of things for granted […] I’m much more switched on to everything […]”

—http://www.usatoday.com/sports/golf/pga/2011-07-18-british-open_n.htm

entry.title: Project Management Truisms
entry.content:
The sooner you begin coding the later you finish.

A badly planned project will take three times longer than expected - a well-planned project only twice as long as expected.

There are no good project managers - only lucky ones.

Everyone asks for a strong project manager - when they get him they don’t want him.

Some projects finish on time in spite of project management best practices.

Fast - cheap - good: you can have any two.

The first 90% of a project takes 90% of the time the last 10% takes the other 90%.

If everything is going exactly to plan, something somewhere is going massively wrong.

—Falkayn’s Nest: Agile software, Ruby on Rails, ASP.NET, eLearning, technology, politics and marketing stuff

entry.title: As Kid After Kid...
entry.content:
as kid after kid talked at me with that twinkle that you see in someone’s eye when confidence, skill, and passion come together in the right mix.
—Maker Faire RI rocked

entry.title: Being Fully Aware...
entry.content:
being fully aware of the present moment, (rather than being pre-occupied with the past or future,) creates a window through which the voice of inspiration can fly directly to us.
—* Brother David Steindle-Rast: Inspiration Lives in the Present | Cross-Cultural Inspiration

entry.title: Unconditional Acceptance...
entry.content:
unconditional acceptance by parents as well as teachers should be accompanied by “autonomy support”: explaining reasons for requests, maximizing opportunities for the child to participate in making decisions, being encouraging without manipulating, and actively imagining how things look from the child’s point of view.
—Mind - When a Parent’s Love Comes With Conditions - NYTimes.com

entry.title: This Year..
entry.content:
This year, since remembering that I create EVERYTHING in my life, I’ve gone through the following phases:

Phase 1 - ooh, I don’t like being around these people who want to have battles when I want cooperation and consultation… I think they need to change

Phase 2 - ooh, I don’t like being in this job where I have to fight battles when really I want cooperation and consultation…. I think I need to leave

Phase 3 - *clunk*…. so, if I create my reality wherever I am, I guess I better change this reality or I’m just gonna keep taking it with me into the next job.

I’m now in Phase 4 which is daydreaming how fabulous each meeting and encounter will be before I get there. It’s WAY more peaceful to come to everything from that space, and if the people I meet choose to retain their old behaviours I’m not engaging. It’s none of my business. :-)

—Habits of Tension? » Good Vibe Blog

entry.title: Barry Schwartz on Our Loss of Wisdom
Project Management in Real Life
OS X Sleep and Hibernate
entry.content:
To view current hibernation mode: (default for portables is 3, desktops use 0)

pmset -g|grep hibernatemode

sleep (3): save to RAM, until low battery, then hibernate

sudo pmset -a hibernatemode 3

hibernate (1): save directly to disk, consumes no power (can even remove battery?)

sudo pmset -a hibernatemode 1

hibernation disabled (0): goes to sleep, dies without power

sudo pmset -a hibernatemode 0
